abstract: The mother of a terminally ill child writes that her story is not that different from the rest of ours: we are all preparing for when our children leave us, or we leave them.
snippet: The mother of a terminally ill child writes that her story is not that different from the rest of ours: we are all preparing for when our children leave us, or we leave them.
lead_paragraph: My father has always said that raising children is a process of letting go. From the moment your children are born, your job is to prepare them to function in the world without you, and perhaps your biggest challenge is preparing yourself for that separation. I couldn't help hearing my father's voice this weekend, while reading Emily Rapp's moving piece in The Times's Sunday Review about having a son with Tay-Sachs, a rare and untreatable genetic disorder from which he will probably die before he turns 3. As Ms. Rapp writes, her story is closer to most of ours than we would like to imagine: on some level, we are all getting ready for the day when our children leave us or we leave them. Read her story, "Notes From a Dragon Mom," and then come back here to share your thoughts.

headline.main: Raising Children Means Letting Them Go
